coredata.dc:title: Isotope-dependent quenching of singlet molecular oxygen (1Δg) by ground-state oxygen in several perhalogenated solvents
coredata.dc:creator: Afshari, Ebrahim
Schmidt, Reinhard
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The deactivation of O2(1Δg) by ground-state O2 was investigated by the direct time-resolved phosphorescence technique in four perhalogenated solvents at 295 K. A very strong isotope effect of k 16 Q/k 18 Q=70 was observed on the quenching rate constant, which is reproduced by the model developed by Maier, Wild, Klingshirn and Plötz for O2(1Δg) deactivation in pure O2. Thus, solvent molecules do not support quenching by O2. k 16 Q ranges from 2600 M−1 s−1 in perfluorohexane to 4100 M−1 s−1 in perflourodecalin and is about three times larger than in gaseous 16O2. The variation of k 16 Q correlates with changes in the packing fraction of the solvents.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 184, number 1,2,3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETITERS 20 September 1991 1802, however, proceeds about two orders of mag- nitude slower at 295 K [6]. The surprisingly large isotope effect on the collisional deactivation of 02( A8) in pure 02 was interpreted successfully by Maier and co-workers by considering the coupled transitions 1. Introduction The main deactivation process of singlet molecu- lar oxygen 02( A5) in solution is quenching by ter- minal oscillators X Y of solvent molecules. Its rate constant ~ depends strongly on ~ the highest fundamental vibrational energy of X Y [1,21. ~ increases by about four orders of magnitude if ~ variesfrom 1250cm- (C F) to 3400cm- (0 H). The linear correlation of in ~ with ~ is repro- duced by a model basing on collision-induced cou- pling of the highest frequency vibration of X Y to the possible vibronic transitions of 02 [1 4]. The competing deactivation channels are described by tAg, v=0+3E~, v =O ~3~,v=m+3~, u=5 m+Em (2) and the different off-resonance energies Em of both isotopes [6,7]. Em has to be transformed into translational energy for the diatomic quencher 02. Consequently, the acceptance of the off-resonance energy is much more difficult for 02 than for polyatomic quenchers. (1) Therefore, slight changes in Em of about 400 cm as observed comparing the quenching of 16O( A8) and 802( A5) by the respective ground-state mole- cules, results in the very strong effect on the quench- ing rate constant [6,71. However, the same change in Emn of eq. (1) has only a moderate effect (factor ~ 7) on the rate constant of 02 ( As) quenching by oscillators X Y if X Y is part of a polyatomic sol- vent molecule [21. If 02 ( A8) quenching by 02 occurs in polyatomic solvents, the picture could be quite different. Colli- sion complexes of 02 and solvent molecule could As, v=O+X-Y(v =0) -, v=rn+X-Y(v =fl)+Emn. The off-resonance energy Em~ can be distributed over the large number of vibrational modes of the entire solvent molecule facilitating the acceptance of the A~ excitation energy by polyatomic quenchers. This is, of course, not the case for diatomic quenchers. Pure, natural oxygen (99.8% 1602) in its ~I; ground state acts in the gas phase and in the liquid phase as a rather strong quencher of 1602( ~) [5 7]. The deactivation of 802( A5) by ground-state 128 0009-26 14/91/$ 03.50 1991 Elsevier Science Publishers BY. All rights reserved. Isotope-dependent quenching of singlet molecular oxygen ( Ag) by ground-state oxygen in several perhalogenated solvents Ebrahim Afshari and Reinhard Schmidt Jnstitutflir Physikalischc Chernie, Universitat Frankfurt, Niederurseler hang, W-6000 Frankurt am Main, Germany Received 28 May 1991; in final form 24 June 1991 The deactivation of 02 ( ~) by ground-state 02 was investigated by the direct time-resolved phosphorescence technique in four perhalogenated solvents at 295 K. A very strong isotope effect of k~/k~ = 70 was observed on the quenching rate constant, which is reproduced by the model developed by Maier, Wild. Klingshim and Pldtz for 02 ( its) deactivation in pure 02. Thus, solvent molecules do not support quenching by 02. k~ ranges from 2600 M - s in perfluorohexane to 4100 M s in perfluorode- calm and is about three times larger than in gaseous 1602 The variation of k~ correlates with changes in the packing fraction of the solvents. Volume 184, number 1,2,3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 20 September 1991 provide suitable accepting modes for the off-reso- nance energy leading to an increase in the rate con- stant kLf and a decrease in the k~6/k~f isotope effect. In this Letter, we report for the first time results on the quenching of the isotopes 602( A5) and 1802 ( As) by the respective ground-state molecules in solution, determined by the time-resolved phos- phorescence technique. Measurements have been made in several perhalogenated solvents, where sep- aration of quenching by 02 and by the solvent is pos- sible already at 02 partial pressures Pc2 c I bar. 2. Experimental The solvents used were perfluorodecalin (PFD, 95%) from Fluka, 1,1 ,2-trichlorotrifluoroethane (freon 113, Uvasol) from Merck, perfluorohexane (PFH, 99%), and tetrachloromethane (TET, 99 + %) from Aldrich. All solvents were purified by repeated column chromatography with neutral A1203 (Woelm). 5,10,1 5,20-tetraphenylporphine (TPP, Gold Label) and phenalenone (P HE) were from Aldrich. PHE was crystallized twice from ethanol. Natural oxygen of 99.5% purity (1602) was sup- plied from Messer Griesheim and 02 (isotopic pu- rity 9 7.6%) from Merck, Sharp and Dome. Solutions of defined concentrations [021 were prepared by four freeze pump thaw cycles on a vacuum line at io~ mbar followed by addition of 02 to the degassed so- lutions at 295 K. A digital pressure meter Piezovac PV ill from Leybold Heraeus (0 1030 mbar) was used to measure the vapor pressure p~ of the solvents and the total pressure Pt after adding 02. Low con- centrations [02] ~ lO~ M were prepared from ox- ygenated solutions (P0, 200 mbar) by three sub- sequent freeze pump thaw cycles reducing 1021 by a factor of about 1000. 02 ( A8) was produced by sensitization with PHE. The instrumentation for time-resolved 02 ( As) phosphorescence measure- ments at 1275 nm for lifetimes r~> 7 ms is described in detail in ref. [21. Excitation pulse energy was less than 10 j.tJ, pulse duration 10 ms. The evaluation of the experimental decay curves E ( t), which are con- volutes of monoexponential 02( A8) decay, broad excitation pulse shape (duration 10 ms) and elec- tronic response function of the Ge detector (3.5 ms), was performed with an improved computer pro- gram. The experimentally determined fluorescence decay of TPP at 660 nm serves as excitation function F(t) of our system. It is the convolution of excita- tion pulse and detector response function. The pro- gram convolutes P( 1) with the monoexponential de- cay B exp ( t/t~) yielding A (t), which is fitted to E(1) using the Marquardt algorithm [8]. 02( A8) lifetimes obtained by this improved procedure are 30% shorter than the values r~> 7 ms estimated with the simpler program in our earlier work 12]. 3. Results Fig. I shows example plots of the experimental 02( A8) phosphorescence decay curve, E(t), and the corresponding excitation function, F(1). The best fit, A (1), for the calculated convolution of monoexpo- nential decay and P( 1) is also given as the super- imposed curve in fig. 1. Very close descriptions of the experimental curves could be achieved. To avoid undesired quenching of 02 ( A8) by the sensitizer PHE, we determined A8 lifetimes in de- pendence of [PHE] in PFD. The linear Stern Vol- mer plot gave the quenching rate constant k~ = 3.2x 10~ M r . Depending on the experiment 3.5xl06~[PHE]~l.5xl05 M was chosen, I, S 1 S 8 Fig. I. Excitation function F(s) measured as time-dependent flu- orescence intensity of TPP in C6H6 at 660 nm. Experimental de- cay E( 5) of ~o2( A5) phosphorescence at 1275 nm in air-satu- rated PFD; [PHE] = 1.3x lOtM. Both decays recorded under identical excitation conditions; Aac = 365 nm. A(s) is the con- volution of F(s) with Bexp( t/r~) calculated to fit E(t). ms. 0.2 Time tel 129 Volume 184, number 1,2,3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 20 September 1991 keeping 02( A8) quenching by PHE negligible. Table I lists A8 lifetimes of air saturated and highly diluted solutions of I602 and 802. The comparison demonstrates that in perhalogenated solvents, quenching of 1602 ( A8) by air takes place. The effect depends on the 02 solubility coefficient and, because of Pa, ~Pt p~, on the vapor pressure of the liquid. The dominant quencher of air is ~02. N2 deacti- vates 02( A8) at least ten times weaker than ~602 [5]. In addition, the solubility of N2 is only about 60% of the 02 value in most organic solvents. The I60,( A8) lifetimes in degassed solvents are distinctly longer than the values published earlier by us for air-satu- rated solvents (PFH: 96, freon 113: 99, and TET: 87 ms [2,3]). However, even the largest deviation by the factor 2 is not so important as to cause a revision of the interpretation of the huge solvent effect on the 02 ( A8) deactivation. The maximum value of 6t~ is observed in PFD with 309 ms. In agreement with our previous results, C F oscillators deactivate ~02( A8) distinctly weaker than C Cl, for which already a heavy-atom effect operates [3]. In the last column, values of 8tA are given which exceed 6ta in the mean by about 40%. The implications of the weak but sig- nificant 02 isotope effect on the mechanism of 02 ( A8) deactivation by solvent molecules will be discussed in a separate publication [9]. Figs. 2 and 3 illustrate the deactivation of ~t~2(~A8) and 802( A8) by the respective ground- state molecules. For both isotopes, the data are rea- sonably described by straight lines corresponding to quenching rate constants of k~ =4100 300 M s and k~,!=60 t5M s . Thus, a very strong isotope effect k)~/kU = 70 on the quenching of 02(A5) by 02 in PFD results. [11]. ~ Extrapolated according to ref. 1121. a) Air saturated. 6) [16021 ~ 100M. c) [ ~02] ~ 10 M. 130 System k~ (M c ) k)t/k3 perhalogenated solvent, 295 K 2600 4100 70 gaseous02,295K t020~ l7Oa) (120)6) liquid 02, 77K 640 c) 460c (460) b) Volume 184, number 1,2,3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 20 September 1991 deactivation by 02 still occurs in solution in a bi- molecular collision, as it takes place in pure gaseous or liquid 02. Maier and co-workers developed a model for the 02 ( A8) quenching by 02 describing the probability P( m) of a single deactivation event as product of a proportionality constant K, of the Franck Condon factors F of the coupled transitions of A8 and ~ according to eq. (2) and of an off-resonance factor f depending on Em, on the temperature T, on the re- duced mass ji, and on the parameters a and E of the attractive Morse potential between the colliding 02 molecules [7], P(m)=KFs(tn)Fx(5 sn)f(Em, T,p, a, ). (3) The total transition probability is obtained as the sum P= ~ F(,n) over the different relaxation channels. In agreement with the experimental result, k~/k~ =460 was calculated by Maier et al. at 77 K [7]. Using the same model and parameters, we cal- culate at 295 K k~~f/k)f = 120. This value agrees as well with the result obtained in the gas phase, as with the isotope effect determined in PFD, see table 3. Thus, we suppose that also in solution, deactiva- tion of 02( A8) by 02 occurs only in binary colli- sions but not in collisions with complexes of 02 and solvent molecule. The large isotope effect demon- strates that the off-resonance energy has to be con- verted in solution at least primarily into transla- tional energy of the colliding 02 molecules. The moderate increase of k~ in solution com- pared to the gas-phase value at 295 K is probably due to variations of the 02 02 collision frequency and not a consequence of solvent-assisted distribution of off-resonance energy. As discussed by Chatelet et al., the following equation holds for the quenching rate constant [14], where F is the deactivation proba- bility per collision: ferent indirect method [13]. These authors mea- sured the bleaching of 1 ,3-diphenylisobenzofurane at different [02] in the high-pressure domain (Po2 100 bar) after excitation of 02 by 1066 nm giant pulses of a Nd: YAG laser. The agreement of the results is amazing in view of the very complex technique used. The data of table 2 indicate a weak but significant solvent effect on ki~ which increases from PFFI to PFD by about 60%. The values of k~j are much more uncertain and should be regarded as upper limits for the rate constant. Due to the low quenching activity of 802 and the very long lifetimes of 802( A8) in perhalogenated solvents, these systems are extremely sensitive to contaminations by quenchers. Actually repeated cycles of evacuation and filling with 1802 lead finally in an irreproducible way to reduced life- times. In good solvents with large vapor pressure, as for example TET, this effect is so dominant that no value of k~8 can be given. In contrast, with PFD, which has the worst solubility properties and the lowest vapor pressure, the most reproducible results have been obtained. We, therefore, assume the value of k~/k~ = 70 measured in PFD as the most real- istic one. 4. Discussion In table 3, our data on the quenching of 02( A8) by 02 in solution are compared with results of Maier et al. obtained in gaseous and liquid 02 [6,7]. Only a moderate increase of k~ and a weak decrease of are noted if solution-phase and gas-phase values at 295 K are considered. Apparently 02 ( A8) Table 3 Quenching of 02( A,) by 02 kQ=PZ. (4) The collision frequency Z is directly proportional to the pair distribution function, depending in the liquid phase but not in the vapor phase on the num- ber density is of the solvent. Chatelet et al. deter- mined experimentally for the isothermal gas (g) liquid (2) phase transition at 150 K, k~(Q)/k~(g) 131 a) Ref [6]. ~ Calculated from the model and the parameters given in ref [7]. C) Ref [73. Volume 184, number 1,2,3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 20 September 1991 = 1.34 [141. With further increasing density, the pair distribution function and, thus, k~(2) still increase. n corresponds via eq. (5) and the 02 van der Waals volume, Vw= 13 cm3 mol [15], with the packing fraction q, and the weak solvent dependence are qualitatively explained by the packing-fraction dependence of the collision frequency. (5) To illustrate the influence of the packing fraction on the rate constant, we take the following data pairs (k~f(Q), M r ; i~) from the results obtained by Chatelet et a]. at 150 K in pure liquid 02: 840, 0.38; 1020, 0.43; and 1740,0.49 [14]. Thus, kt~ increases distinctly with q. j is even larger in perhalogenated solvents at room temperature. From literature data on van der Waals volumes, we calculate ,j(PFH) =0.51, ~(freon 113)=0.52, q(TET)=0.54 and ~(PFD)=0.57 [15]. Exactly in the same order of solvents, k~ increases, as can be seen from table 2. Hence, the difference of the quenching rate con- stants between gas phase and solution phase and the weak solvent effect on are caused by variations of the 02 02 collision frequency which depends via the pair distributioa function on the packing frac- tion of the solvent [14,16]. 5. Conclusions The strong ~ 180 isotope effect on the rate constant of 02 ( Ag) quenching by 02 is described quantitatively by a model developed by Maier and co-workers for pure 02 systems [6,7]. Therefore, deactivation occurs in binary collisions of 02 mol- ecules in perhalogenated solvents as well as in pure 02. Electronic excitation energy is converted into vi- brational energy, off-resonance energy into transla- tional energy of the colliders. Assistance by solvent molecules during acceptance of the off-resonance en- ergy does not occur. The moderate increase of k~ in solution compared to the gas-phase value at 295 K 132 . Only a moderate increase of k~ and a weak decrease of are noted if solution-phase and gas-phase values at 295 K are considered. Apparently 02 ( A8) Table 3 Quenching of 02( A,) by 02 kQ=PZ. (4) The collision frequency Z is directly proportional to the pair distribution function, depending in the liquid phase but not in the vapor phase on the num- ber density is of the solvent. Chatelet et al. deter- mined experimentally for the isothermal gas (g) liquid (2) phase transition at 150 K, k~(Q)/k~(g) 131 a) Ref [6]. ~ Calculated from the model and the parameters given in ref [7]. C) Ref [73. Volume 184, number 1,2,3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 20 September 1991 = 1.34 [141. With further increasing density, the pair distribution function and, thus, k~(2) still increase. n corresponds via eq. (5) and the 02 van der Waals volume, Vw= 13 cm3 mol [15], with the packing fraction q, and the weak solvent dependence are qualitatively explained by the packing-fraction dependence of the collision frequency. head.ce:title: Isotope-dependent quenching of singlet molecular oxygen (1Δg) by ground-state oxygen in several perhalogenated solvents

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Institut für Physikalische Chemie, Universität Frankfurt, Niederurseler Hang, W-6000 Frankfurt am Main, Germany

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The deactivation of O2(1Δg) by ground-state O2 was investigated by the direct time-resolved phosphorescence technique in four perhalogenated solvents at 295 K. A very strong isotope effect of k 16 Q/k 18 Q=70 was observed on the quenching rate constant, which is reproduced by the model developed by Maier, Wild, Klingshirn and Plötz for O2(1Δg) deactivation in pure O2. Thus, solvent molecules do not support quenching by O2. k 16 Q ranges from 2600 M−1 s−1 in perfluorohexane to 4100 M−1 s−1 in perflourodecalin and is about three times larger than in gaseous 16O2. The variation of k 16 Q correlates with changes in the packing fraction of the solvents.

ce:other-ref.ce:textref: E. Afshari and R. Schmidt, J. Phys. Chem., to be submitted for publication.
